channel.title: Basic Java conventions - Naming of methods, variables etc
channel.description:
In the programming community, it is *expected* that you follow the conventions. People are less inclined to help you if you fail to do so, your code is less readable in most cases (especially if you fail to indent it), and in some cases people won't read your stuff period.
The instructions below will show you how to *properly* name variables, methods, classes and so on.
[b]Naming Methods:[/b] [i]In the case of this forum, many of you identify a method as either a public void, public boolean and public ints. In the case of booleans and ints, they're 'methods' when they take parameters (Stuff between the () that appears at the end of the method name), or when they carry out something *before* returning a value, or when they simply carry a return statement, which will return a value dependant on that method's type.
Naming methods is simple: Just start them with a lower case letter, and for every consecutive word (any word after the first word in the name) start it with a *capital* letter. So the first word starts with a *lowercase or little* letter, and any following words start with a *uppercase or big* letter. Do not separate the words with underscores.
An example: simpleMethodName - As you can see, simple starts with a lowercase s, and the following words method and name start with uppercase characters.[/i]
[b]Naming Variables:[/b] [i]Variables are named in the same manner as methods - The first word in the variable's name starts with a lowercase letter, and all following words start with a capital letter.[/i]
[b]Naming Contants:[/b] [i]Constants are something seldom seen here on the forums, but I'll demonstrate how they should be named anyway; you never know when you might find them useful. (Constants could be used as level requirements and the like).
Constants look like this: [/i]
[code]public final int CONSTANT_NAME[/code] [i] The keyword that identifies a constant is 'final'. Constants are 'final' because no part of your program can change their value while the program is running - Should any of your code try to change a constant, a compile time error will occur whilst compiling.
As you can see above, the name of the final int is CONSTANT_NAME - That's an example of how you name contants, or 'final' variables. You capitalise *all* letters, and separate words with an underscore - It really is that simple. :eek:[/i]
[b]Naming Classes:[/b] [i]Classes should have all words start with a capital letter. An example of this:[/i] [code]public class NewClassName[/code]
[i]The name of the class in that example is 'NewClassName'. As you can see, all words begin with a capital letter, and there are no spaces or underscores.
If a class is prefixed with the 'public' modifier, it must have its own file. So say I actually made the class NewClassName - It would have to go in its own file called NewClassName.java. More then one class can go in each Java file, but only one of those classes can be a 'public' class, and the file name must *always* be named identically to that class. If you don't make the filename the same as the public class' name inside, a compile time error will occur.[/i]
[b]Indentation:[/b] [i]Indentation is another one of those *things* that can make or break your code when you want to share it with others. You might not mind that the code is hard to read, and looks like shit. However, if you want to post it as a tutorial, I suggest you indent it so others can read and follow what's happening easily.
An example of indentation:[/i] [code]public class Hi { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("This is indented code"); } }[/code]
[i]As you can see, I've moved my lines of code inwards - This basically makes it easy to see that the method 'main' is a part of the class 'Hi'. It also makes it easy to see that the line being printed is being printed by the main method. Try 4 space indentation - 4 spaces is half the size of a tab in notepad.[/i]
[b]I hope this has been somewhat... educational. Taking these things on-board when you program will improve the quality of your code when others go to use/read it and add to it.[/b]

item.source: Basic Java conventions - Naming of methods, variables etc

item.title: Basic Java conventions - Naming of methods, variables etc
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

Lothy, you forgot to mention:

When naming instance variables first do public, then protected, then package level (no access modifier), and then private.

When naming Class Variablies first do the public class variables, then the protected, then package level (no access modifier), and then the private.

Also, when coding try to keep lines less then 80 characters, because most terminals don’t handle them well

[size=1pt]Found on http://java.sun.com/docs/codeconv/html/CodeConvTOC.doc.html[/size]

Read full topic
